title: 114_hr4109
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled the "Protecting Financial Aid for Students and Taxpayers Act." Congress found a significant increase in enrollment at for-profit institutions of higher education from 1998 to 2013. These institutions received a substantial amount of Federal Pell Grants and student loans. Additionally, for-profit institutions were top recipients of Post-9/11 Educational Assistance funds, receiving billions in taxpayer funds. For-profit institutions of higher education spend 28 percent of expenditures on advertising, marketing, and recruiting. SEC. 2. RESTRICTIONS ON FUNDS FOR RECRUITING AND MARKETING. Section 119 of the Higher Education Opportunity Act is amended to include restrictions on using Federal educational assistance funds for recruiting and marketing activities at institutions of higher education. The Higher Education Opportunity Act now restricts the use of Federal educational assistance funds for recruiting and marketing activities at institutions of higher education, including advertising, promotion, and efforts to attract prospective students. The Higher Education Opportunity Act limits the use of Federal educational assistance funds for recruiting and marketing activities at institutions of higher education, including paying employees for enrollment oversight and contacting potential students, soliciting contact information, and other activities as determined by the Secretary. The Higher Education Opportunity Act restricts the use of Federal educational assistance funds for various activities at institutions of higher education, as determined by the Secretary of Education. This includes sponsoring education or military-related associations and exceptions are made for activities required by law or authorized under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Higher Education Opportunity Act limits the use of Federal educational assistance funds at institutions of higher education under specific provisions of law, including Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, Title 38 of the United States Code, Title 10 of the United States Code, the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, and the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act. This section does not restrict the use of revenues from sources other than Federal educational funds. Institutions receiving Federal educational assistance funds must report annual expenditures on advertising, marketing, and recruiting to the Secretary and Congress.
